pages.text: Lanthanum is a chemical element with the symbol La and atomic number 57. It is a soft, ductile, silvery-white metal that tarnishes slowly when exposed to air and is soft enough to be cut with a knife. It is the eponym of the lanthanide series, a group of 15 similar elements between lanthanum and $(l:materials/Lutetium)lutetium$(/l) in the periodic table, of which lanthanum is the first and the prototype. It is also sometimes considered the first element

of the 6th-period transition metals, which would put it in group 3, although $(l:materials/Lutetium)lutetium$(/l) is sometimes placed in this position instead, for example in the left-step model. Lanthanum is traditionally counted among the rare earth elements. The usual oxidation state is +3. Lanthanum has no biological role in humans but is essential to some bacteria. It is not particularly toxic to humans but does show some antimicrobial activity.

Lanthanum usually occurs together with $(l:materials/Cerium)cerium$(/l) and the other rare earth elements. Lanthanum was first found by the Swedish chemist Carl Gustav Mosander in 1839 as an impurity in $(l:materials/Cerium)cerium$(/l) nitrate - hence the name lanthanum, from the Ancient Greek λανθάνειν (lanthanein), meaning "to lie hidden". Although it is classified as a rare earth element, lanthanum is the 28th most abundant element in the Earth's crust, almost three times as abundant as

$(l:materials/Lead)lead$(/l). In minerals such as monazite and bastnäsite, lanthanum composes about a quarter of the lanthanide content. It is extracted from those minerals by a process of such complexity that pure lanthanum metal was not isolated until 1923.$(p)Lanthanum compounds have numerous applications as catalysts, additives in glass, $(l:materials/Carbon)carbon$(/l) arc lamps for studio lights and projectors, ignition elements in lighters
and torches, electron cathodes, scintillators, GTAW electrodes, and other things. Lanthanum carbonate is used as a phosphate binder in cases of renal failure.
